A new major version of `mapsf` has been deployed on CRAN.   
This new release introduces some new features and fixes and also few backward incompatible changes. In this post I'll show some of the new features of the package: 

- The new theming system
- The updated display of map elements
- The updated Cheat Sheet
- A new way of designing color palettes





### Dataset
The dataset used in the following examples is about apartment rental prices in 2023 (<small>[source](https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/datasets/carte-des-loyers-indicateurs-de-loyers-dannonce-par-commune-en-2023/#/resources/43618998-3b37-4a69-bb25-f321f1a93ed1)</small>).  
<small>Download the dataset:</small> [{{< fa download >}}](com.gpkg)

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
com <- sf::st_read("com.gpkg", quiet = TRUE)
```
:::




## New cartographic themes

A new theming system has been introduced, it has lead to new default values and a new default map style.   
**`mf_theme()`** sets a map theme. A theme is a set of graphical parameters that are applied to maps created with `mapsf`. These parameters are figure margins; frames; background, foreground and highlight colors; default sequential and qualitative palettes; title options (position, size, banner, etc.).  
Themes are persistent across maps produced by `mapsf` (e.g. they survive a `dev.off()` call). 


### The default theme
The default theme is called "base". 


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(mapsf)
mf_theme("base")
mf_map(com)
mf_title("New default theme")
mf_scale()
mf_credits()
mf_arrow()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-2-1.png){width=480}
:::
:::



### Builtin themes

`mapsf` offers some builtin themes. It's possible to modify an existing theme or to start a theme from scratch. If you want to have a look at the 8 builtin themes you can go to the vignette about themes on `mapsf` website: [link](link)


::: {.cell layout-ncol="2"}

```{.r .cell-code}
mf_theme("sol_light")
mf_map(com, 'loypredm2', 'choro', breaks = "ckmeans", nbreaks = 4)
mf_title('sol_light theme')
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-1.png){width=384}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
mf_theme("sol_light", highlight = "brown", title_banner = TRUE, pal_seq = "Teal")
mf_map(com, 'loypredm2', 'choro', breaks = "ckmeans", nbreaks = 4)
mf_title('Modified sol_light theme')
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-2.png){width=384}
:::
:::



### How to get back to the former default

If you need to use the former (pre v1.0.0) default theme, use "default": 


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
mf_theme(x = "default")
mf_map(com)
mf_title("Former default theme")
mf_scale()
mf_credits()
mf_arrow()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-4-1.png){width=288}
:::
:::


## Better display of map elements

In this new version, map elements are redrawn when the graphic device is resized. This behaviour is a great improvement for interactive map displays, particularly when using RStudio and Positron.

## Updated Cheat Sheet

The cheat sheet has been updated to reflect the changes that has happened in the package. 


![](front.png)


## Diverging color palettes

`mf_get_pal()` has been modified to make it easier to create diverging color palettes based on a vector of break values. 

In the first example, we create a vector of break values based on the mean and the standard deviation of the distribution. We use `central = FALSE` to have the mean as a break value. Then we use `mf_get_pal()` with the breaks vector, the mean value and 2 color palette names to create the corresponding diverging color palette.

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
bks_1 <- mf_get_breaks(x = com$loypredm2, breaks = "msd", central = FALSE)
pal_1 <- mf_get_pal(breaks = bks_1, mid = mean(com$loypredm2), 
                    palette = c("Burg", "Teal"))
```
:::


In the second example, we use the same method but this time the mean is in the middle of a central class (`central = TRUE`). The resulting palette has a neutral color for the central classe that contains the mean value.

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
bks_2 <- mf_get_breaks(x = com$loypredm2, breaks = "msd", central = TRUE)
pal_2 <- mf_get_pal(breaks = bks_2, mid = mean(com$loypredm2), 
                    palette = c("Burg", "Teal"))
```
:::





::: {.cell layout-ncol="2"}

```{.r .cell-code}
mf_theme(x = "base", title_cex = 1, frame = "map")
mf_map(com, "loypredm2", "choro", breaks = bks_1, pal = pal_1)
mf_title("Diverging color palette")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-7-1.png){width=384}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
mf_map(com, "loypredm2", "choro", breaks = bks_2, pal = pal_2)
mf_title("Diverging color palette with a neutral color")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-7-2.png){width=384}
:::
:::



::: {.callout-note title="Classification based on mean and standard deviation"}
This method proposes to form classes based on the value of the standard deviation and the mean. This method of classification does not allow you to directly choose a number of classes, but allows you to choose the portion of the standard deviation which corresponds to the size of a class as well as the role of the mean (used as a class boundary or as a class center).  
<small>[Magrit documentation](https://magrit.cnrs.fr/en/functionalities/classification.html#mean-and-standard-deviation)<small/>
:::
